metadata.document_name: 42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks
metadata.source_pdf: 42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf
metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
key_issues: The appellant's trade mark application for the word mark "COOLPOLY" was rejected by the Registrar of Trade Marks under Section 9(1)(a) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, for lack of distinctive character.
The application was also initially objected to under Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, for relative grounds of refusal, but this objection was later dropped.
The Registrar held that the mark "COOLPOLY" is a combination of two English words, "COOL" and "POLY", and is not inherently distinctive.
The mark was found to be descriptive of the goods in respect of which its registration was sought, which includes plastic and carbon moulding materials and moulded heat sinks for use in computers.
The application was filed on a "proposed to be used" basis, and the Registrar held that the mark had not acquired any secondary meaning.
The appellant's failure to overcome the objections raised by the Registrar resulted in the rejection of the application.
The Trade Marks Act, 1999, provides that a trade mark shall not be registered if it is devoid of any distinctive character, which is a key issue in this case.

The distinction between absolute and relative grounds of refusal for trade mark registration is relevant to this case, with the absolute grounds being based on the inherent characteristics of the mark and the relative grounds being based on the existence of earlier similar marks.

The concept of secondary meaning, which refers to the acquisition of distinctiveness through use, is also relevant to this case, as the appellant's application was filed on a "proposed to be used" basis.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary: TICONA POLYMERS, INC. vs. REGISTRAR OF TRADE MARKS**

**Background:**
The appellant, TICONA POLYMERS, INC., filed an application (No. 2847019) on November 19, 2014, to register the word mark "COOLPOLY" under the Trade Marks Act, 1999. The application sought registration in two classes: Class 1 for plastic and carbon moulding materials and Class 9 for moulded heat sinks, electrical conductors, and parts and components thereof. The application was initially scrutinized, and a First Examination Report (FER) was issued on January 13, 2016, objecting to the registration of the mark under Sections 9(1)(a) and 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act.

**Legal Issues:**
The main issues in this case are:

1. Whether the mark "COOLPOLY" is inherently distinctive and capable of distinguishing the goods of the appellant from those of others.
2. Whether the mark is descriptive of the goods in respect of which its registration is sought.
3. Whether the mark has acquired a secondary meaning, despite being registered on a "proposed to be used" basis.

**Arguments:**
The appellant argued that the mark "COOLPOLY" is distinctive and not descriptive of the goods. The appellant also submitted that the mark has been registered in various jurisdictions, which suggests that it is capable of distinguishing the goods of the appellant from those of others.

**Court Findings:**
The Senior Examiner, in the impugned order, dropped the objections under Sections 11 and 12 of the Trade Marks Act. However, the Examiner rejected the application on the ground that "COOLPOLY" is merely a combination of the two English words "COOL" and "POLY", which is not inherently distinctive and is descriptive of the goods. The Examiner also found that, as the registration was sought on a "proposed to be used" basis, the mark had not acquired any secondary meaning.

**Decision:**
The High Court of Delhi, in this appeal, considered the objections raised by the Senior Examiner and the arguments made by the appellant. The court ultimately held that the mark "COOLPOLY" is not registrable under the Trade Marks Act, 1999, as it lacks inherent distinctiveness and is descriptive of the goods.

**Key Points:**

* The court agreed with the Senior Examiner that the mark "COOLPOLY" is merely a combination of two English words and is not inherently distinctive.
* The court found that the mark is descriptive of the goods, as it suggests that the goods are "cool" and made of "poly" material.
* The court held that, as the registration was sought on a "proposed to be used" basis, the mark had not acquired any secondary meaning.
* The court dismissed the appeal, upholding the decision of the Senior Examiner to reject the application for registration of the mark "COOLPOLY".

**Conclusion:**
In this case, the High Court of Delhi upheld the decision of the Senior Examiner to reject the application for registration of the mark "COOLPOLY" under the Trade Marks Act, 1999. The court found that the mark lacks inherent distinctiveness, is descriptive of the goods, and has not acquired any secondary meaning. This decision highlights the importance of ensuring that trademarks are distinctive and not descriptive of the goods or services in respect of which they are sought to be registered.

--- PAGE 1 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 1 of 8 
 
 
$~2 
* 
IN  THE  HIGH  COURT  OF  DELHI  AT  NEW  DELHI 
+  
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022 
 
TICONA POLYMERS, INC.  
 
    ..... Appellant 
Through: 
Ms. 
Aamna 
Hasan, 
Mr. 
Vaibhav 
Vutts 
and 
Mr. 
Devadathan 
Jayachandran, Advs. 
 
 
 
 
 
versus 
 
 
REGISTRAR OF TRADE MARKS  
    ..... Respondent 
Through: 
Mr. 
Harish 
Vaidyanathan, 
CGSC with Mr. Srish Kumar Mishra, Mr 
Sagar Mehlawat, Mr. Alexander Mathai 
Paikaday, Advs. 
 
 
CORAM: 
 
HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE C.HARI SHANKAR 
 
 
 
 
JUDGMENT (ORAL) 
% 
 
 
 
         28.02.2023 
 
1. 
This appeal, under Section 91 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, 
assails order dated 26th October 2020 passed by the Senior Examiner 
in the office of the Registrar of Trade Marks, whereby Application 
No. 2847019, filed by the appellant for registration of the word mark 
―COOLPOLY‖, in (i) Class 1 in respect of plastic and carbon 
moulding materials for use in the manufacture of moulded plastic 
articles and (ii) Class 9 in respect of moulded heat sinks for use in 
computers and parts and components thereof and moulded electrical 
conductors, was rejected. 
 
2. 
Application No. 2847019 was filed by the appellant on 19th 
November 2014.  Consequent to a preliminary scrutiny, First 
Examination Report (FER) dated 13th January 2016 was issued by the 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 2 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 2 of 8 
 
 
Registrar, objecting to the registration of the aforesaid mark 
COOLPOLY under Sections 9(1)(a)1 and 11(1) (though not expressly 
quoted) of the Trade Marks Act.  The objections in the FER read thus: 
 
―1.  The trade marks which are devoid of any distinctive 
character, that is to say, not capable of distinguishing the goods 
or services of one person from those of another person; 
 
2.  
The Trade Mark application is open to objection on 
relative grounds of refusal under Section 11 of the Act because 
the same/similar trade mark(s) is/are already on record of the 
register for the same or similar goods/services.  The detail of 
same/similar trade marks is enclosed herewith  
 
Save as provided in Sec. 12, a trade mark shall not be 
registered if, because of-its identity with an earlier trade mark 
and similarity of goods or services covered by; the trade mark; 
or its similarity to an earlier trade mark and the identity or 
similarity of the goods or services covered by the trade mark,‖ 
 
3. 
 Additionally, the FER required the appellant to file the duly 
stamped TM-48 which, Ms. Aamna Hasan submits, was filed. 
 
4. 
Of the aforesaid two objections raised in the FER, the impugned 
order has dropped the objections predicated on Sections 11 and 12.  
The Senior Examiner proceeds, thereafter, to reject the appellant’s 
application on the ground that  
(i) 
COOLPOLY was merely a combination of the two 
English words COOL and POLY, 
(ii) 
COOLPOLY, as a whole, was not inherently distinctive,  
(iii) the mark was, on the other hand, descriptive of the goods 
in respect of which its registration was sought, and 
                                          
1 9.  
Absolute grounds for refusal of registration. –   
(1)  
The trade marks –  
(a)  
which are devoid of any distinctive character, that is to say, not capable of 
distinguishing the goods or services of one person from those of another person; 
***** 
 
shall not be registered. 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 3 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 3 of 8 
 
 
(iv) 
as registration was sought on a ―proposed to be used‖ 
basis, it had not acquired any secondary meaning. 
(It is not clear from the impugned order, which is extremely clumsily 
written and worded, whether the Senior Examiner finds COOLPOLY 
as a whole to be descriptive or whether she finds COOL and POLY 
individually to be descriptive.)  
  
5. 
The following passage from the impugned order contains what 
may be called the reasoning of the Senior Examiner: 
 
―Adv. Aamna Hasan appeared and argued and submitted that. 
Goods have no reference to mark, and the mark is registered in 
various jurisdictions so consider as a distinctive. Thirdly sec. 11 
is not applicable, heard, and checked the details of application, it 
appears that, total five opportunities of hearing given. As per 
details on record and submission made by advocate it appears 
that, the cited marks are visually ,phonetically, and conceptually 
different, so obj. u/s 11 waived, moreover obj. u/s 9 is sustain 
because mark as a whole is not inherently distinctive, it is a 
mere combination of an English word "coolpoly" which is not 
distinctive and descriptive to applied goods of "[CLASS-1] 
Plastic and carbon molding materials for use in the manufacture 
of molded plastic articles.[CLASS-9] Molded heat sinks for use 
in computers and parts and components therefore and molded 
electrical conductors." .the mark is mere combination of word 
"cool" and "poly" hence it is not inherently distinctive, so no one 
can claim any exclusive right over the descriptive word, until 
and unless the mark has acquired distinctiveness by long and 
continuous commercial use and Mark is descriptive in nature 
and has direct reference to goods applied, it has describes 
quality and intended purpose, further more it is a proposed to be 
used mark, so not having user so no acquired secondary 
meaning. The adv. Also submitted that, the mark is registered in 
various jurisdiction so consider as distinctive, whereas trans-
border reputation or goodwill is not recognized by the Hon. 
Supreme court in landmark judgment of PRIUS. Furthermore, it 
is a well settled law that, mere combination of two known word 
or abbreviation thereof would not be an invented word, even 
though the combination may not have been in use before, if to 
the eyes or ear the same idea would be conveyed as by the 
words in its ordinary form, as decided in the cases of "E. 
                                                                                                                   
Provided that a trade mark shall not be refused registration if before the date of 
application for registration it has acquired a distinctive character as a result of the use made of it or 
is a well-known trade mark. 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 4 of 8 
 
 
Griffiths Hughes Ltd. vs Vick Chemical Co. AND A.R. Khaleel 
And Sons vs Registrar of Trade Marks In India", so upon 
considering the material on record, and submission made by the 
advocate, the applicant and adv. is fail to prove the justification 
for waving off obj. raised under sec.9 (1)(a) trade Mark Act 
1999.‖ 
 
6. 
Aggrieved, the appellant has appealed to this Court. 
 
7. 
I have heard Ms. Aamna Hasan, learned Counsel for the 
appellant and Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan, learned Counsel for the 
respondent. 
 
8. 
None of the considerations on which the Senior Examiner has 
rejected the appellant’s application commend themselves to 
acceptance. 
 
9. 
In the first place, the learned Senior Examiner was required to 
examine the entitlement to registration, of the COOLPOLY mark as a 
whole, and not by breaking it into COOL and POLY.   
 
10. 
The Senior Examiner has, in rejecting the appellant’s 
application for registration of the COOLPOLY mark, proceeded on 
the reasoning that COOLPOLY was a mere portmanteau of the words 
COOL and POLY, each of which was descriptive of the nature of the 
goods in respect of which registration of the mark was sought.  As 
such, the Senior Examiner holds that the mark was not inherently 
distinctive as required by Section 9(1)(a) of the Trademarks Act. 
 
11. 
 It is well settled that a mark cannot be dissected into its 
individual parts while examining its entitlement to registration.  
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 5 of 8 
 
 
Though Section 17(1)2 of the Trademarks Act statutory embodies this 
anti-dissection principle in the context of infringement proceedings, 
the principle would apply, mutatis mutandis, even at the stage when 
the mark is examined for its entitlement for registration as it is only 
the factum of registration which brings, in its wake, the privileges that 
follow, including protection against infringement.  
 
12. 
Seen as a whole, it cannot be said that the word COOLPOLY 
has any etymological meaning or significance in the English language.  
It is not a word of common – or, for that manner, even uncommon – 
usage, as would render it incapable of distinguishing goods of one 
person from those of another if used as a trade mark.  Indeed, the 
impugned order is silent as to why the mark is not distinctive.  Rather, 
the Senior Examiner appears to have, clearly erroneously, conflated 
the concept of lack of distinctiveness, addressed by Section 9(1)(a), 
and descriptiveness, addressed by Section 9(1)(b), and confused the 
two.   
 
13. 
Section 9(1)(a) would apply only where a mark was so common 
and so lacking in distinction as would make it impossible, on the basis 
of that mark, to distinguish between the goods of one person and 
goods of another. Common English words and phrases of everyday 
usage would fall within this category.  Such common English words 
cannot be registered as marks, unless they enjoy the benefit of the 
                                          
2 17.  
Effect of registration of parts of a mark. –  
(1)  
When a trade mark consists of several matters, its registration shall confer on the 
proprietor exclusive right to the use of the trade mark taken as a whole. 
(2)  
Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), when a trade mark— 
(a)  
contains any part –  
(i)  
which is not the subject of a separate application by the proprietor for 
registration as a trade mark; or 
(ii)  
which is not separately registered by the proprietor as a trade mark; or 
(b)  
contains any matter which is common to the trade or is otherwise of a non-
distinctive character, 
the registration thereof shall not confer any exclusive right in the matter forming only a part of the 
whole of the trade mark so registered. 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 6 of 8 
 
 
proviso to Section 9(1), which would apply where the mark, before the 
date of registration, has acquired distinctiveness –in trade mark 
terminology, a ―secondary meaning‖ –  by dint of long or continuous 
use, or is a ―well known trade mark‖ within the meaning of Section 
2(1)(zg)3 of the Trade Marks Act.    
 
14. 
The impugned order does not hold that COOLPOLY is a word 
of common English usage.  Indeed, as already noted, COOLPOLY has 
no meaning.  The impugned order does not cite any other mark of any 
other person, similar to ―COOLPOLY‖ or provide any reason as to 
why the use of the mark ―COOLPOLY‖ in respect of goods for which 
registration was sought by the appellant would make it impossible to 
distinguish between the said goods or any other goods available in the 
market. 
 
15. 
Adverting, next, to the aspect of descriptiveness, COOLPOLY, 
being a word with no meaning, can obviously not be regarded as 
descriptive of the goods in respect of which registration was sought by 
the appellant.  For that matter, it cannot be said that either of the parts 
of the mark ―COOL‖ or ―POLY‖, even seen individually, is 
descriptive of the nature of the goods in respect of which registration 
was sought.  Registration of the mark ―COOLPOLY‖ was sought in 
respect of plastic and carbon moulding materials used in the 
manufacture of moulded plastic articles and moulded heat sinks for 
use in computers and parts and components thereof and moulded 
electrical conductors.  The impugned order is silent as to how the 
words ―COOL‖ and ―POLY‖ even if seen individually, are descriptive 
                                          
3 (zg)  
―well-known trade mark‖, in relation to any goods or services, means a mark which has become so 
to the substantial segment of the public which uses such goods or receives such services that the use of such 
mark in relation to other goods or services would be likely to be taken as indicating a connection in the course 
of trade or rendering of services between those goods or services and a person during the mark in relation to 
the first-mentioned goods or services. 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 7 of 8 
 
 
of the products in respect of which registration was sought or were 
wanting any distinctive character. 
 
16. 
The basic prerequisites of Section 9(1)(a) do not appear to be 
addressed in the impugned order.  In a sense, the impugned order is 
unreasoned, as it merely holds, as the mere ipse dixit of the Senior 
Examiner, that the expression ―COOL‖ and ―POLY‖ were descriptive 
of the products in respect of which registration was sought.   
 
17. 
This Court is not inclined to agree with the said reasoning or 
conclusion.  In the opinion of the Court, 
(i) 
COOLPOLY cannot, for examining distinctiveness, be 
vivisected into COOL and POLY, 
(ii) 
COOLPOLY is not a word of common English usage, 
(iii) COOLPOLY, if used as a mark by one person is, 
therefore, perfectly capable of distinguishing the goods or 
services of that person, in respect of which the mark is used, 
from the goods and services of others, 
(iv) 
the proscription against registration contained in Section 
9(1)(a) would not, therefore, apply, 
(v) 
neither COOLPOLY, nor COOL and POLY individually 
seen, are descriptive of the goods in respect of which the 
appellant sought registration of the COOLPOLY mark and 
(vi) 
the proscription against registration contained in Section 
9(1)(b) would also, therefore, not apply. 
 
18. 
As such, the impugned order, which is unsustainable in law or 
on facts, is quashed and set aside.   
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 8 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 8 of 8 
 
 
19. 
As the application of the appellant has yet to be advertised, the 
application is remanded to the Registrar to advertise the mark and 
proceed thereafter in accordance with the provisions of the 
Trademarks Act and the Trademarks Rule.   
 
20. 
The appeal stands allowed accordingly with no orders as to 
costs. 
 
21. 
Ms. Hasan prays that a direction for a time bound decision may 
be passed.  This Court is hesitant to do so as this Court is not aware of 
the amount of work which is pending before the Registrar.  However, 
Mr. Vaidyanathan very fairly undertakes to ensure that there would be 
no delay in the matter.   
 
22. 
Let this order be uploaded on the website of this Court within 
24 hours. 
 
 
 
 
C.HARI SHANKAR, J 
FEBRUARY 28, 2023  
rb 
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Case Header and Parties
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard an appeal (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022) filed by Ticona Polymers, Inc. against the Registrar of Trade Marks. The appeal challenged the order dated October 26, 2020, which rejected the registration of the word mark "COOLPOLY" under Sections 9(1)(a) and 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.

The application for registration was filed on November 19, 2014, for use in Class 1 and Class 9 products, including plastic and carbon moulding materials and moulded heat sinks for computers. The Registrar's office initially objected to the registration, citing lack of distinctive character and similarity with existing trademarks.

However, the Senior Examiner eventually rejected the application solely on the ground that "COOLPOLY" was not inherently distinctive and descriptive of the goods. The appellant argued against this decision, and the case was heard by Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar on February 28, 2023.

The PDF document provides details of the legal proceedings, including the parties involved, their representatives, and the dates of key events. The case highlights the complexities of trademark registration and the importance of distinctive character in determining the registrability of a mark. (Source: Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf)

nodes.summary: According to page 1 of the PDF "42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi is hearing an appeal (C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022) filed by Ticona Polymers, Inc. against the Registrar of Trade Marks. The appeal is under Section 91 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, and challenges an order dated October 26, 2020, rejecting the appellant's Application No. 2847019 for registration of the word mark "COOLPOLY" in Class 1 and Class 9. The application was filed on November 19, 2014. The case is being heard by Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar, with the appellant represented by Ms. Aamna Hasan, Mr. Vaibhav Vutts, and Mr. Devadathan Jayachandran, and the respondent represented by Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan and others. The judgment was delivered orally on February 28, 2023.

nodes.title: Page 2
nodes.summary: According to page 2 of the PDF "42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the Registrar of Trade Marks objected to the registration of the mark "COOLPOLY" under Sections 9(1)(a) and 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act. The objections included that the mark lacked distinctive character and was similar to existing trademarks. The Senior Examiner rejected the application, stating that "COOLPOLY" was a descriptive combination of "COOL" and "POLY" and not inherently distinctive. The appellant, Ticona Polymers, Inc., was represented by Ms. Aamna Hasan, among others. The case is listed as C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022 with a Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/001489. The decision was digitally signed by Sunil Singh Negi on March 1, 2023. (Source: PDF "42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", page 2)

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", a legal proceeding is ongoing in the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi, with case number C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022. The appellant, Ticona Polymers, Inc., is represented by Ms. Aamna Hasan, Mr. Vaibhav Vutts, and Mr. Devadathan Jayachandran, while the respondent, Registrar of Trade Marks, is represented by Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan and others.

The Background and Facts section reveals that the Senior Examiner rejected the appellant's application for registration of the trademark "COOLPOLY" under Section 9(1)(a) of the Trade Mark Act 1999, citing that the mark is not inherently distinctive and is a combination of descriptive words "cool" and "poly". The examiner also noted that the mark had not acquired secondary meaning as it was proposed to be used and had no trans-border reputation.

The appellant argued that the mark is distinctive and has been registered in various jurisdictions. However, the Senior Examiner relied on precedents, including "E. Griffiths Hughes Ltd. vs Vick Chemical Co." and "A.R. Khaleel And Sons vs Registrar of Trade Marks In India", to support the decision.

The appeal is now before the High Court, with the appellant challenging the rejection of their application. The court has heard arguments from both parties, and the decision is pending. The PDF document, dated March 1, 2023, provides details of the legal proceedings, including the Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/001489.
tree_structure.pdf_source: 42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 3
nodes.summary: According to page 3 of the PDF "42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the Senior Examiner rejected the registration of the trademark "COOLPOLY" citing that it is descriptive and not inherently distinctive. The Examiner found that the mark is a combination of the English words "cool" and "poly", which describes the quality and intended purpose of the goods. The applicant's argument that the mark is registered in various jurisdictions was dismissed, as trans-border reputation or goodwill is not recognized by the Supreme Court. The Examiner also noted that the mark was applied for on a "proposed to be used" basis and had not acquired any secondary meaning. The case is C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022, with the appellant Ticona Polymers, Inc. represented by Ms. Aamna Hasan, among others, and the respondent Registrar of Trade Marks represented by Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan, among others.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 3 of 8 
 
 
(iv) 
as registration was sought on a ―proposed to be used‖ 
basis, it had not acquired any secondary meaning. 
(It is not clear from the impugned order, which is extremely clumsily 
written and worded, whether the Senior Examiner finds COOLPOLY 
as a whole to be descriptive or whether she finds COOL and POLY 
individually to be descriptive.)  
  
5. 
The following passage from the impugned order contains what 
may be called the reasoning of the Senior Examiner: 
 
―Adv. Aamna Hasan appeared and argued and submitted that. 
Goods have no reference to mark, and the mark is registered in 
various jurisdictions so consider as a distinctive. Thirdly sec. 11 
is not applicable, heard, and checked the details of application, it 
appears that, total five opportunities of hearing given. As per 
details on record and submission made by advocate it appears 
that, the cited marks are visually ,phonetically, and conceptually 
different, so obj. u/s 11 waived, moreover obj. u/s 9 is sustain 
because mark as a whole is not inherently distinctive, it is a 
mere combination of an English word "coolpoly" which is not 
distinctive and descriptive to applied goods of "[CLASS-1] 
Plastic and carbon molding materials for use in the manufacture 
of molded plastic articles.[CLASS-9] Molded heat sinks for use 
in computers and parts and components therefore and molded 
electrical conductors." .the mark is mere combination of word 
"cool" and "poly" hence it is not inherently distinctive, so no one 
can claim any exclusive right over the descriptive word, until 
and unless the mark has acquired distinctiveness by long and 
continuous commercial use and Mark is descriptive in nature 
and has direct reference to goods applied, it has describes 
quality and intended purpose, further more it is a proposed to be 
used mark, so not having user so no acquired secondary 
meaning. The adv. Also submitted that, the mark is registered in 
various jurisdiction so consider as distinctive, whereas trans-
border reputation or goodwill is not recognized by the Hon. 
Supreme court in landmark judgment of PRIUS. Furthermore, it 
is a well settled law that, mere combination of two known word 
or abbreviation thereof would not be an invented word, even 
though the combination may not have been in use before, if to 
the eyes or ear the same idea would be conveyed as by the 
words in its ordinary form, as decided in the cases of "E. 
                                                                                                                   
Provided that a trade mark shall not be refused registration if before the date of 
application for registration it has acquired a distinctive character as a result of the use made of it or 
is a well-known trade mark. 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 4
nodes.summary: According to page 4 of the PDF "42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the Senior Examiner rejected the appellant's application for registration of the COOLPOLY mark, citing that it was a mere portmanteau of descriptive words COOL and POLY. The Examiner held that the mark was not inherently distinctive as required by Section 9(1)(a) of the Trademarks Act. The appellant, Ticona Polymers, Inc., appealed to the High Court of Delhi, which heard arguments from Ms. Aamna Hasan for the appellant and Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan for the respondent. The Court noted that the Examiner should have examined the entitlement to registration of the COOLPOLY mark as a whole, rather than breaking it down into individual parts. The case is C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022, with a Neutral Citation Number of 2023/DHC/001489.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 4 of 8 
 
 
Griffiths Hughes Ltd. vs Vick Chemical Co. AND A.R. Khaleel 
And Sons vs Registrar of Trade Marks In India", so upon 
considering the material on record, and submission made by the 
advocate, the applicant and adv. is fail to prove the justification 
for waving off obj. raised under sec.9 (1)(a) trade Mark Act 
1999.‖ 
 
6. 
Aggrieved, the appellant has appealed to this Court. 
 
7. 
I have heard Ms. Aamna Hasan, learned Counsel for the 
appellant and Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan, learned Counsel for the 
respondent. 
 
8. 
None of the considerations on which the Senior Examiner has 
rejected the appellant’s application commend themselves to 
acceptance. 
 
9. 
In the first place, the learned Senior Examiner was required to 
examine the entitlement to registration, of the COOLPOLY mark as a 
whole, and not by breaking it into COOL and POLY.   
 
10. 
The Senior Examiner has, in rejecting the appellant’s 
application for registration of the COOLPOLY mark, proceeded on 
the reasoning that COOLPOLY was a mere portmanteau of the words 
COOL and POLY, each of which was descriptive of the nature of the 
goods in respect of which registration of the mark was sought.  As 
such, the Senior Examiner holds that the mark was not inherently 
distinctive as required by Section 9(1)(a) of the Trademarks Act. 
 
11. 
 It is well settled that a mark cannot be dissected into its 
individual parts while examining its entitlement to registration.  
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the legal proceedings are between Ticona Polymers, Inc. (Appellant) and Registrar of Trade Marks (Respondent) with case number C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022. The Neutral Citation Number is 2023/DHC/001489.

The Appellant argued that the Respondent erred in not registering the trade mark "COOLPOLY" under Section 9(1)(a) of the Trademarks Act. The Appellant's counsel, Ms. Aamna Hasan, Mr. Vaibhav Vutts, and Mr. Devadathan Jayachandran, claimed that the mark is distinctive and not descriptive of the goods.

The Respondent's Senior Examiner had conflated the concept of lack of distinctiveness and descriptiveness, which are addressed by Sections 9(1)(a) and 9(1)(b) respectively. The Appellant argued that "COOLPOLY" has no etymological meaning or significance in the English language and is not a word of common usage.

The document also references Section 17(1)2 of the Trademarks Act, which embodies the anti-dissection principle, and Section 2(1)(zg)3, which defines a "well-known trade mark". The Appellant claimed that the Respondent did not provide any reason why the mark "COOLPOLY" would make it impossible to distinguish between goods.

The case was digitally signed by Sunil Singh Negi on March 1, 2023. The PDF document provides further details on the legal arguments and proceedings. (Source: Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf)
tree_structure.pdf_source: 42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 5
nodes.summary: According to page 5 of the PDF "42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the court discusses the anti-dissection principle in trademark registration. The principle, embodied in Section 17(1) of the Trademarks Act, applies to both infringement proceedings and registration examinations. The court argues that the mark "COOLPOLY" has no etymological meaning and is not a common word, making it distinctive. The Senior Examiner mistakenly conflated lack of distinctiveness (Section 9(1)(a)) with descriptiveness (Section 9(1)(b)). The court references Section 17(1) and Section 9(1)(a) to support its argument. The case, C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022, is ongoing in the High Court of Delhi. The PDF document is dated March 1, 2023, and is signed by Sunil Singh Negi. (Source: "42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", page 5)
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 5 of 8 
 
 
Though Section 17(1)2 of the Trademarks Act statutory embodies this 
anti-dissection principle in the context of infringement proceedings, 
the principle would apply, mutatis mutandis, even at the stage when 
the mark is examined for its entitlement for registration as it is only 
the factum of registration which brings, in its wake, the privileges that 
follow, including protection against infringement.  
 
12. 
Seen as a whole, it cannot be said that the word COOLPOLY 
has any etymological meaning or significance in the English language.  
It is not a word of common – or, for that manner, even uncommon – 
usage, as would render it incapable of distinguishing goods of one 
person from those of another if used as a trade mark.  Indeed, the 
impugned order is silent as to why the mark is not distinctive.  Rather, 
the Senior Examiner appears to have, clearly erroneously, conflated 
the concept of lack of distinctiveness, addressed by Section 9(1)(a), 
and descriptiveness, addressed by Section 9(1)(b), and confused the 
two.   
 
13. 
Section 9(1)(a) would apply only where a mark was so common 
and so lacking in distinction as would make it impossible, on the basis 
of that mark, to distinguish between the goods of one person and 
goods of another. Common English words and phrases of everyday 
usage would fall within this category.  Such common English words 
cannot be registered as marks, unless they enjoy the benefit of the 
                                          
2 17.  
Effect of registration of parts of a mark. –  
(1)  
When a trade mark consists of several matters, its registration shall confer on the 
proprietor exclusive right to the use of the trade mark taken as a whole. 
(2)  
Notwithstanding anything contained in sub-section (1), when a trade mark— 
(a)  
contains any part –  
(i)  
which is not the subject of a separate application by the proprietor for 
registration as a trade mark; or 
(ii)  
which is not separately registered by the proprietor as a trade mark; or 
(b)  
contains any matter which is common to the trade or is otherwise of a non-
distinctive character, 
the registration thereof shall not confer any exclusive right in the matter forming only a part of the 
whole of the trade mark so registered. 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary: According to page 6 of the PDF "42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the court discusses the registrability of the trade mark "COOLPOLY" under the Trade Marks Act. The impugned order does not hold that "COOLPOLY" is a word of common English usage, nor does it cite any similar marks. The court argues that "COOLPOLY" is not descriptive of the goods for which registration was sought, including plastic and carbon moulding materials. The mark's components, "COOL" and "POLY", are also not descriptive of the goods. The case is C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022, with the appellant Ticona Polymers, Inc. and the respondent Registrar of Trade Marks. TheNeutral Citation Number is 2023/DHC/001489.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 6 of 8 
 
 
proviso to Section 9(1), which would apply where the mark, before the 
date of registration, has acquired distinctiveness –in trade mark 
terminology, a ―secondary meaning‖ –  by dint of long or continuous 
use, or is a ―well known trade mark‖ within the meaning of Section 
2(1)(zg)3 of the Trade Marks Act.    
 
14. 
The impugned order does not hold that COOLPOLY is a word 
of common English usage.  Indeed, as already noted, COOLPOLY has 
no meaning.  The impugned order does not cite any other mark of any 
other person, similar to ―COOLPOLY‖ or provide any reason as to 
why the use of the mark ―COOLPOLY‖ in respect of goods for which 
registration was sought by the appellant would make it impossible to 
distinguish between the said goods or any other goods available in the 
market. 
 
15. 
Adverting, next, to the aspect of descriptiveness, COOLPOLY, 
being a word with no meaning, can obviously not be regarded as 
descriptive of the goods in respect of which registration was sought by 
the appellant.  For that matter, it cannot be said that either of the parts 
of the mark ―COOL‖ or ―POLY‖, even seen individually, is 
descriptive of the nature of the goods in respect of which registration 
was sought.  Registration of the mark ―COOLPOLY‖ was sought in 
respect of plastic and carbon moulding materials used in the 
manufacture of moulded plastic articles and moulded heat sinks for 
use in computers and parts and components thereof and moulded 
electrical conductors.  The impugned order is silent as to how the 
words ―COOL‖ and ―POLY‖ even if seen individually, are descriptive 
                                          
3 (zg)  
―well-known trade mark‖, in relation to any goods or services, means a mark which has become so 
to the substantial segment of the public which uses such goods or receives such services that the use of such 
mark in relation to other goods or services would be likely to be taken as indicating a connection in the course 
of trade or rendering of services between those goods or services and a person during the mark in relation to 
the first-mentioned goods or services. 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi made a decision in the case C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022. The appellant, Ticona Polymers, Inc., was represented by Ms. Aamna Hasan, Mr. Vaibhav Vutts, and Mr. Devadathan Jayachandran, while the respondent, Registrar of Trade Marks, was represented by Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan. 

The court decided that the expression "COOLPOLY" is capable of distinguishing the goods or services of the appellant and is not descriptive of the products in respect of which registration was sought. The court quashed and set aside the impugned order, which had rejected the appellant's application for trademark registration. 

The court remanded the application to the Registrar to advertise the mark and proceed in accordance with the Trademarks Act and Rules. The appeal was allowed with no orders as to costs. The court also directed that the order be uploaded on the website of the court within 24 hours. The decision was made by Justice C. Hari Shankar on February 28, 2023. The digitally signed document was verified on March 1, 2023. The source of this information is the PDF document "Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", specifically pages 1-8, with Neutral Citation Number 2023/DHC/001489.
tree_structure.pdf_source: 42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 7
nodes.summary: According to page 7 of the PDF "42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the High Court of Delhi ruled in favor of the appellant, Ticona Polymers, Inc. The court disagreed with the Registrar of Trade Marks' decision to reject the registration of the trademark "COOLPOLY". The court held that "COOLPOLY" is not descriptive of the goods and is capable of distinguishing the appellant's goods from others. The court quashed and set aside the impugned order, citing that the prerequisites of Section 9(1)(a) were not addressed. The decision was made on March 1, 2023, by Judge Sunil Singh Negi. The case number is C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022. The court's decision overturns the rejection of the trademark registration, allowing Ticona Polymers to proceed with registering "COOLPOLY" as a trademark.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 7 of 8 
 
 
of the products in respect of which registration was sought or were 
wanting any distinctive character. 
 
16. 
The basic prerequisites of Section 9(1)(a) do not appear to be 
addressed in the impugned order.  In a sense, the impugned order is 
unreasoned, as it merely holds, as the mere ipse dixit of the Senior 
Examiner, that the expression ―COOL‖ and ―POLY‖ were descriptive 
of the products in respect of which registration was sought.   
 
17. 
This Court is not inclined to agree with the said reasoning or 
conclusion.  In the opinion of the Court, 
(i) 
COOLPOLY cannot, for examining distinctiveness, be 
vivisected into COOL and POLY, 
(ii) 
COOLPOLY is not a word of common English usage, 
(iii) COOLPOLY, if used as a mark by one person is, 
therefore, perfectly capable of distinguishing the goods or 
services of that person, in respect of which the mark is used, 
from the goods and services of others, 
(iv) 
the proscription against registration contained in Section 
9(1)(a) would not, therefore, apply, 
(v) 
neither COOLPOLY, nor COOL and POLY individually 
seen, are descriptive of the goods in respect of which the 
appellant sought registration of the COOLPOLY mark and 
(vi) 
the proscription against registration contained in Section 
9(1)(b) would also, therefore, not apply. 
 
18. 
As such, the impugned order, which is unsustainable in law or 
on facts, is quashed and set aside.   
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf

nodes.title: Page 8
nodes.summary: According to page 8 of the PDF "42. Ticona Polymers v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi made a decision on the appeal C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022. The application of Ticona Polymers, Inc. is remanded to the Registrar to advertise the mark and proceed according to the Trademarks Act and Rules. The appeal is allowed with no orders as to costs. The Court declined to set a time-bound decision but Mr. Vaidyanathan undertook to ensure no delay. The order was to be uploaded on the Court's website within 24 hours. The decision was made by Justice C. Hari Shankar on February 28, 2023. The PDF document is a court record with a Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/001489.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001489 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 89/2022  
Page 8 of 8 
 
 
19. 
As the application of the appellant has yet to be advertised, the 
application is remanded to the Registrar to advertise the mark and 
proceed thereafter in accordance with the provisions of the 
Trademarks Act and the Trademarks Rule.   
 
20. 
The appeal stands allowed accordingly with no orders as to 
costs. 
 
21. 
Ms. Hasan prays that a direction for a time bound decision may 
be passed.  This Court is hesitant to do so as this Court is not aware of 
the amount of work which is pending before the Registrar.  However, 
Mr. Vaidyanathan very fairly undertakes to ensure that there would be 
no delay in the matter.   
 
22. 
Let this order be uploaded on the website of this Court within 
24 hours. 
 
 
 
 
C.HARI SHANKAR, J 
FEBRUARY 28, 2023  
rb 
 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:01.03.2023
16:56:15
Signature Not Verified
